newsitem.title: USA: Buddhist denies U.S. donations were made for favors.
newsitem.headline: Buddhist denies U.S. donations were made for favors.

text.p: The Buddhist leader at the the center of a fund-raising scandal over alleged illegal contributions to the Democratic Party said he was not seeking political favors for his donations, the Los Angeles Times reported on Saturday.

Venerable Master Hsing Yun, who raised $140,000 for the Democratic National Committee during a luncheon attended by Vice President Al Gore during the 1996 presidential campaign, said his temple's donation was made to thank the United States for its long support of Taiwan .

The Buddhist leader made the comments in a written statement to Senate investigators, obtained by the Los Angeles Times. The statement was turned over to the investigators earlier this summer in Taiwan, the paper said.

The newspaper reported that, in the statement, the 70-year-old monk and founder of the Hsi Lai Temple in the Los Angeles suburb of Hacienda Heights said the fund-raiser for Gore had no political agenda and was aimed at building mainstream acceptance of Buddhism in America.
The temple is at the center of a scandal because it solicited donations from clerics, nuns and devotees at the temple and then reimbursed them with funds from the temple's bank account.
By doing this the temple effectively donated $50,000 to the DNC while keeping its identity concealed. Federal election law prohits concealing the identity of a donor.
"We do not quite understand American law," Yun said in the statement. "You can correct us and we will mend our ways."

The document contradicts earlier theories that the donations came from foreign sources and fails to shed new light on Democratic fund-raisers John Huang and Maria Hsia who reportedly solicited the temple donations.
